questions.question: ………………………….. trying hard, she couldn’t finish the job.
questions.description: Despite is a preposition. It is followed by a noun. In spite of is also possible here.

questions.question: ……………………………. she worked hard, she didn’t get the promotion.
questions.description: Although is used to connect two contrasting ideas. It is a conjunction and is followed by a clause.

questions.question: ………………………… I knew no one at the party, I had a nice time.
questions.description: Though is used to connect two contrasting ideas. It is a conjunction and is followed by a clause.

questions.question: ………………………… my pleas for help, he didn't move.
questions.description: In spite of is used to connect two contrasting ideas. It is a preposition.

questions.question: I insist that she …………………………… dismissed.
questions.description: Should is not normally used in the clause after insist.

questions.question: I recommend that the factory ………………………….. moved to another place.
He insisted …………………………. for the drink.
questions.description: Insist is followed by on + ing form.

questions.question: ……………………….. my childhood was full of misery, my adulthood is peaceful.
questions.description: While is used to connect two contrasting ideas. Though is also possible here.

questions.question: I went to a shop ………………………….. they sell dry fruits.
She worked hard ………………………… she might get the promotion.
questions.description: We use so that and in order that to indicate purpose.

questions.question: ……………………….. his stamina, he is a good athlete.
questions.description: Due to is similar to because of.

questions.question: I tried scuba diving …………………………. my fears.
